title: 104_hr3923
content: The "Aviation Disaster Family Assistance Act of 1996" allows the National Transportation Safety Board to provide assistance to families of passengers involved in aircraft accidents. The "Aviation Disaster Family Assistance Act of 1996" authorizes the National Transportation Safety Board to designate a director of family support services for families of passengers involved in aircraft accidents. The "Aviation Disaster Family Assistance Act of 1996" authorizes the National Transportation Safety Board to designate an independent nonprofit organization to coordinate emotional care for families of passengers involved in accidents. The Board is responsible for facilitating recovery and identification of fatally-injured passengers, while the designated organization provides mental health and counseling services in coordination with the air carrier's disaster response team. The Aviation Disaster Family Assistance Act of 1996 authorizes an independent nonprofit organization to coordinate emotional care for families of passengers involved in accidents. The organization is responsible for providing private grieving environments, meeting with families, and communicating roles of involved parties post-accident. The Aviation Disaster Family Assistance Act of 1996 authorizes an independent nonprofit organization to coordinate emotional care for families of passengers involved in accidents. The organization is responsible for arranging a suitable memorial service in consultation with the families and requesting passenger lists from the air carrier or foreign air carrier involved in the accident. The Aviation Disaster Family Assistance Act of 1996 allows an independent nonprofit organization to request passenger lists from the air carrier involved in an accident. The organization can provide information about a passenger to their family as deemed appropriate. The National Transportation Safety Board must ensure that families of passengers involved in the accident are briefed before any public briefing. The National Transportation Safety Board ensures that families of passengers involved in an accident are briefed on the causes and findings before any public briefing. The organization designated for an accident must coordinate with the air carrier to utilize their resources effectively. No person or entity is allowed to impede the Board's ability to carry out its responsibilities. The National Transportation Safety Board and designated organizations must ensure families of passengers involved in an accident are briefed on findings. No unsolicited communication regarding legal action can be made to individuals or relatives within 30 days of the accident. The term 'aircraft accident' refers to any aviation disaster, regardless of its cause. A passenger includes an employee of an air carrier aboard an aircraft. Section 1136 of the title addresses assistance to families of passengers involved in aircraft accidents. Penalties under Section 1155(a)(1) are amended to include violations of Section 1136(g). Air carriers are required to have plans in place to address the needs of families of passengers involved in aircraft accidents. Each air carrier holding a certificate of public convenience and necessity must submit a plan within 6 months of the enactment of this section to address the needs of families of passengers involved in aircraft accidents resulting in a major loss of life. The plan should include a toll-free telephone number for handling calls from the public. The air carrier must submit a plan within 6 months of the enactment of this section to address the needs of families of passengers involved in aircraft accidents. The plan should include a toll-free telephone number and a process for notifying families before public notice of passenger names. The carrier must assure prompt notification to families and provide support services designated for the accident. The air carrier must provide a list of passenger names upon request, consult with families about remains and personal effects, and return any possessions to the family if requested. The air carrier must assure that unclaimed possessions of passengers will be retained for 18 months, consult with families about monuments, treat all families equally, and collaborate with designated organizations for ongoing support. The air carrier must provide services and assistance to families of passengers following accidents, including compensation to designated organizations, assistance with travel, physical care, and commitment of resources. Additionally, after 6 months from enactment, the Secretary cannot approve a certificate without meeting these requirements. An air carrier must include a plan meeting specific requirements when applying for a certificate of public convenience and necessity. The carrier is not liable for damages related to providing a passenger list unless grossly negligent or intentionally misconduct. Definitions for "aircraft accident" and "passenger" are referenced from another section. SEC. 4. ESTABLISHMENT OF TASK FORCE. Plans to address needs of families of passengers involved in aircraft accidents. Establishment of a task force by the Secretary of Transportation, in collaboration with various entities, to develop a model plan and recommendations for air carriers responding to aircraft accidents. Recommendations include ensuring privacy for families of passengers and preventing intrusion by attorneys and media representatives. The curr_chunk discusses recommendations for assisting families of non-US citizens involved in aircraft accidents, preventing state laws from hindering mental health workers at accident sites, utilizing military experts for passenger remains identification, and improving notification timeliness by air carriers to families. The curr_chunk discusses the analysis of steps for air carriers to provide accurate passenger lists within 1-3 hours of an accident, the added costs to carriers and travel agents, and potential passenger inconveniences. The Secretary must submit a report to Congress within 1 year of the Act's enactment, containing the model plan and recommendations developed by the task force. SEC. 5. LIMITATION ON STATUTORY CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not limit an air carrier's actions or obligations in assisting families of passengers in an aircraft accident.
